title: Tuesday, 10th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:06am

So, here we go again.

BE11:07am

You know what happens. Mostly, the tech fails, which it did on multiple levels this morning

BE11:08am

Starting with me trying to fix an intermittent problem with my PC's PSU, which resulted in a lot of smoke and a broken computer.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Anyway. Where to start?

BE11:08am

Recycling, maybe.

BE11:09am

11:10 am
BE11:10am

..... because the story's back, again.

BE11:10am

HelloFresh on Tuesday outlined plans to make a second attempt at an initial public offering, shrugging off the disappointing market performance of meal kit rival Blue Apron.

The German company said it is looking to raise €250m – €300m in the flotation that it plans to use for funding growth initiatives and new business lines.

BE11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-acfa-52eaee11ed70

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Second? Is it really only the second?

BE11:12am

I guess it depends on what point you consider it pulled. Rocket would've had this thing out the door five times already if they could, and it's only necessity that drives them to this point once more.

BE11:13am

$1.8bn valuation, tho. Because why not.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Baillie Gifford and Qatar went in at an entirely theoretical $2bn valuation in December, of course, but I'm not sure IPOs count in the "no downward rounds" mantra these nonsense businesses apply.

BE11:15am

Anyway, good luck to Berenberg, BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank, JP Morgan and Morgan Stanley, who are all bookrunning this thing.

BE11:16am

Why five on the ticket for a mere quarter-billion euro cash raise? Well ..... you know why.

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:17am

So ............ FTSE's up a tad, 7507 live.

BE11:18am

Domino's requested on the right, happy to go there.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

(The stock, not the place.)

Domino's Pizza Group PLC (DOM:LSE): Last: 343.80, up 41.4 (+13.69%), High: 346.90, Low: 326.80, Volume: 3.51m
BE11:19am

Reassuring on FY, "at least" in line.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Post a decent Q3 where like-for-like was up 8.1%.

BE11:20am

The underlying theme here is that Just Eat, Deliveroo and Uber don't really seem to be growing into Domino's LFLs.

BE11:21am

So, it's a story of promotion bork stuff sorted out a bit and a return to growth. Albeit looping a weaker comparison.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Stifel can summarise.

BE11:22am

Like-for-like sales in the main UK business were up 8.1% in Q3 excluding split territories.

BE11:22am

UK: Like-for-like sales in Q3 increased by 8.1% excluding split stores, a sharp
improvement on the 2.4% reported in H1. Excluding split stores the increase was around
5%. This largely relates to the period before the launch of the Autumn promotion. System
sales increased by 12.1% in the quarter.
We consider the return to strong growth reflects weaker comparatives and more
favourable weather conditions. It clearly dispels the very negative sentiment which
circulated following the interim results.
International: Good progress was achieved with Switzerland up 20.4% in like-for-like
sales, Iceland up 4.0% and Norway up 14.6%.
Outlook: Underlying full year pre-tax profit expected to be at least in line with current
market expectations. Our full year forecast looks underpinned by the good progress.
Valuation: This is a positive update today and dispels the very negative sentiment
following the interim results. The shares have staged a recovery in recent weeks following
the announcement of a £15m share buyback programme.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

And Barclays.

BE11:23am

UK LFLs for the 13 weeks to 24 September are 8.1% on an “excluding splits” basis. This is a material improvement on a sequential basis from 2.4% in H1. At the H1 stage, the including split LFLs were 2.3% lower than the ex-split LFLs (i.e. c0.1% growth). Barclays forecasts are for UK LFLs of 2% in FY17 but based on an “including splits” basis, (i.e. c6% on an ex-splits basis for H2). Bloomberg consensus for UK Q3 LFLs ex-splits were +3.5%. Comscore data illustrated that online usage trends for Domino’s had been broadly unchanged in July and August vs. Q2. That said, comps eased significantly in FY16 to 6.2% (or 3.9% inc splits) and the weather went from being a headwind in the prior year (warmer, less rainfall in Q3 16) to a tailwind this year as shown in the charts below. Consequently, the 2 year LFL is c14% in Q3 vs. 15% in H1, which would be a more cautious interpretation of the data. 18 new stores were opened in the period, taking year to date UK openings to 58 and FY17 expectations are unchanged at 90 new sites (Barclays forecasts: 90 new UK sites). LFLs in the International businesses are all well into positive territory, but we do not consider these as important at this stage given relatively limited impact on EBIT. Outlook statement: The company “anticipate full year underlying profit before tax at least in line with current market expectations”. Barclays forecasts PBT of £89.2m, Bloomberg consensus £89.6m. Capex guidance has been lowered slightly to the lower end of the £50-60m range (Barclays £55m). In addition to fundamentals, we believe the reaction to this statement needs to be seen through the lens of i) a sharp increase in the share price following the share buyback announcement, and ii) related to this, the significant short interest. Valuation: Dec-18e PE 19.6x, EV/EBITDA 14.9x, FCF yield 5.5%, dividend yield 3.0%

BE11:24am

I'm trying to make sense of what Barclays is saying about the weather but can't quite grasp it ....

11:24 am
BE11:24am

BE11:25am

Meanwhile, Citi has a deep dive on pizza if anyone's interested.

BE11:26am

Yeah, really.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

we compare Domino's (DPZ), Pizza Hut (YUM), and Papa John's (PZZA); three of the largest operators in the QSR pizza landscape.

BE11:26am

North America, to be clear.

BE11:27am

And 81 pages.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

BE11:28am

........... It doesn't, at first glance, seem to mention whether the pizzas are any good.

BE11:28am

But perhaps I'm missing the point.

11:28 am
undefined
BE11:29am

Okay, so what else? Apologies at being a bit behind the curve this morning, was chasing other stuff and forgot I was solo.

BE11:29am

There's BAE, I guess.

11:29 am
BAE Systems PLC (BA.:LSE): Last: 617.50, down 1 (-0.16%), High: 617.50, Low: 610.00, Volume: 3.52m
BE11:30am

Confirms a load of job cuts.

BE11:31am

nearly 2k of them, in fact, including 1k from Typhoon.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

It's a first move by new CEO Charles Woodburn, of course, but also a fairly strong signal that the Saudi order won't come through any time soon.

BE11:33am

We've written about this quite recently -- as in, the Saudi budget being set in May with no order, and also the Oman thing looking curious .......

BE11:34am

...........Sorry, not Oman! Qatar. Middle East politics is a subject where I really should be thinking before typing.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Have Kepler before I get myself into trouble.

BE11:35am

BAE Systems is expecting a drastic decline in Typhoon production, with
just 11 Eurofighter Typhoons in 2018 compared to 20 in 2017. The job cuts
will affect BAE’s Warton factory in Preston, Lancashire. The move comes
as the Saudi order for an additional 48 aircraft is still pending. Qatar’s
letter of intent for 24 Typhoon could be a relief, provided it translates into
a firm order. In our view, this does not spell the end of BAE’s hopes for the
Saudi order, but rather indicates that any potential order will require local
assembly, thereby forcing BAE to reduce its industrial footprint in the UK.

BE11:35am

BAE Systems is also set to announce some cuts in the Portsmouth shipyard,
despite some orders booked. These cuts could be an anticipation of a new
UK shipbuilding strategy to force more competition and reduce costs. BAE
systems is usually swift at resizing its workforce according to the end
clients’ future needs

11:35 am
BE11:36am

BAE Systems is set to unveil a wider cost reduction plan, as the company
needs to anticipate potential UK defence shortfalls and the need to
maintain a strong level of competiveness. The fact that 25% of the UK
defence budget will be spent on US equipment by 2020 does not help in
safeguarding the UK defence industrial base either.

BE11:36am

They're buyers up to 700p.

BE11:36am

Our DCF-derived TP at 700p assumes solid cash generation, with cash
conversion at between 65% and 70%. We continue to expect solid
development of the global defence market. Our sales growth assumptions
range from 1% to 4%, with an average at 3%. Relative valuation at 13.5x
EV/ EBIT 2018E and 12.5x 2019E appears relatively full versus European
peers, but still lags behind US peers like Lockheed Martin.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Markets Live. FT Alphaville. Typing. Stuff.

BE11:38am

We believe Saudi Arabia plans to assemble Typhoon aircraft in Kingdom making
it more certain a further Typhoon order will eventually be placed. Meantime,
today’s Trading Update probably signals the decline in Typhoon and Hawk
assembly activity we had forecast spread across FY18 and FY19 actually all
happens in FY18. That works for us – reset expectations for FY18 and then look
forward into FY19. And there should be things to look forward to, in our view.

BE11:38am

The commentary on exports campaigns appears essentially
unchanged. There is to be a streamlining of the organisation with the P&S (UK) and P&S
(International) structures removed and replaced by Air and Maritime. That strikes us as a
whole lot more straightforward for all observers (ending the saga of what bit of what export
orders falls in the UK or International). We note restructuring costs appear to be absorbed
with the FY17 guidance suggesting some outperformance exists somewhere.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Going to keep going on this, because by trying to paraphrase Sandy you only ever lose valuable detail.

BE11:39am

In our note of 19 May 2017, Arms and the Man, we maintained our Hold
recommendation, but tickled our PT up from 600p to 615p. We described the upside and
downside risks as being “quite finely balanced” and stated the breadth of BAE’s business
would likely generate an “averaging effect”. The averaging effect and the balance of risks
remain the same as best we can tell, but the timing of the puts and takes appears to have
changed. C. S. Lewis commented “One fails forward toward success” – and that captures this
particular moment in the BAE equity story, in our view. In short, the decline in Eurofighter
Typhoon revenue we had forecast through FY18 and FY19 looks likely – given the Trading
Update – to all happen in FY18. We suspect Hawk revenue may also be weaker than we
expected. The total headwind to revenue in FY18 could be around £800-900m compared
with the £350m we forecast.

BE11:40am

.... but will skip a bit so as not to annoy Jefferies too much. We return at the long-term outlook.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Once-upon-a-time, the last 48 of the 72 Typhoon aircraft ordered by Saudi
Arabia were going to be assembled in Kingdom, but that plan changed in 2011. Now, the
assembly of Hawk aircraft has begun in Saudi Arabia so an in-Kingdom expertise is building,
an expertise that will probably gravitate towards Typhoon at some point. Elsewhere, passage
of the US FY18 Defense Budget in calendar 2017 or early 2018 might still enhance BAE’s
outlook, even in FY18. The Australian Land 400 programme could also boost BAE’s fortunes
– the outcome looks binary, but then it so often is. Were BAE to win Land 400 and/or Saudi
Arabia were to commit to more Typhoon aircraft and/or Qatar’s intent to purchase Typhoon
aircraft were confirmed, neither FY18 or FY19 revenue would be the focus, in our view. Of
course we will review our forecasts in light of the Trading Update, but there are other issues
that should also be weighed and measured. We should have time to do that, our plan being
to fail forward to success rather than flat on our faces.

BE11:41am

I do like Sandy Morris. He writes about the industrialisation of flaming death from above in such an elegant way.

undefined
11:42 am
BE11:43am

What next, then?

BE11:43am

Pets At Home's just KKR selling a load.

BE11:44am

£119m worth, Merrill did the business overnight.

11:44 am
Pets at Home Group PLC (PETS:LSE): Last: 199.60, down 16.3 (-7.55%), High: 200.10, Low: 195.00, Volume: 5.96m
BE11:45am

195p a share and they're locked in for the next 60 days, for what little that matters.

BE11:46am

.......... otherwise, we have ...........

11:45 am
BE11:46am

U.K. IS SAID TO STUDY JOINING NAFTA IF NO EU DEAL: TELEGRAPH

BE11:46am

Omg smile

BE11:46am

... and more interestingly .........

11:46 am
BE11:46am

*PFIZER REVIEWING OPTIONS FOR CONSUMER HEALTHCARE

BE11:47am

............ so, that's been the rumoured Reckitt deal approximately forever.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,021, up 83 (+1.20%), High: 7,024, Low: 6,948, Volume: 568.31k
11:48 am
BE11:48am

And Pfizer's been investigating a breakup since 2015-ish.

BE11:49am

You'd assume it'd be beyond the reach of Reckitt post Mead, but maybe there's an alternate strategy here involving spinoffs and hosts ....

BE11:49am

Such as the one speculated about here: https://www.ft.com...-9846-de406ccb37f2

11:50 am
BE11:50am

........... and it's at a time when there's been strong rumours about Reckitt exiting household and switching solely to healthcare. Hm. Interesting timing.

BE11:51am

Reckitt has a trading update due middle of this month, I think.

undefined
11:52 am
BE11:52am

Not sure I can be bothered with DPL, but there's a big sector note out of Redburn.

BE11:53am

As we reach the ten-year anniversary of the last peak, investor scrutiny of the
UK new-build housing market is intensifying. Having analysed the difficult
questions, we emerge reassured. Affordability is not the block on demand
that is often portrayed, while gradual interest rate rises would be manageable.
Pent-up demand remains significant following a decade of underactivity,
and Help to Buy is the critical means through which this can be unlocked.
In a stable economic environment, new-build housing trends will continue
to outperform.
The sector’s structural attraction is still land, where a lack of inflation defies
prior cycle experience. The supply of future opportunities should remain
plentiful, amid a benevolent competitive backdrop. Our assessment of latest
landbank positions suggests that, despite cycle age, the full benefits of this are
yet to be felt. We now expect sector margins to edge higher to FY21, versus
our prior assumption of fade.

BE11:53am

Our latest EPS upgrades leave us 4-5% ahead of consensus. But the real draw
is cash flow. In the four years to FY07, the sector generated FCF worth only
5% of sales; in the four years to FY21, this ratio will rise to over 12%. This is a
transformational industry change, made possible by higher margins, reduced
tax rates and, most importantly, low-cost reinvestment.
With a cumulative sector FCF yield of 32% in FY18-21 (despite landbank plot
expansion of 12% en route), and the likeli
hood of strong industry returns
through the early 2020s, we still see meaningful equity upside.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

So everything goes up to buy, except Bovis which doesn't.

Persimmon PLC (PSN:LSE): Last: 2,730, up 32 (+1.19%), High: 2,751, Low: 2,705, Volume: 946.91k
Bovis Homes Group PLC (BVS:LSE): Last: 1,116, down 27 (-2.36%), High: 1,142, Low: 1,115, Volume: 479.39k
11:56 am
BE11:56am

BE11:57am

BE11:58am

Terrible, terrible, terrible policy.

11:58 am
undefined
BE11:59am

So .............. nearly there.

BE12:00pm

Someone was talking about Iomart

12:00 pm
iomart group PLC (IOM:LSE): Last: 349.00, up 12 (+3.56%), High: 352.75, Low: 347.25, Volume: 93.53k
BE12:01pm

All's fine, apparently. I've not read the statement but I assume that's the case.

BE12:01pm

Here's N+1.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

iomart issued a positive pre-close trading update indicating it continues to perform well and is trading in-line with expectations. We are making no changes to our forecasts. The group indicated that it intends to pay a maiden interim dividend this financial year. We recently upgraded iomart to a Buy as we believe its 8.8x Mar’18 EV/EBITDA under values its revenue growth (20% CAGR last 5 years), profitability (EBITDA CAGR of 22% and PBT margins of 24-26%) and cash flow generation (over last 5 years, average operating cash conversion of 97%). Today’s update shows continued solid execution and we re-iterate our positive stance with a 388p TP.

undefined
BE12:06pm

Well, blimey. That's computer #2 killed within the past 90 minutes.

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Laptop this time.

BE12:07pm

I should probably stop buying £10 computers on ebay with the idea that I can fix them, as I clearly cannot.

BE12:08pm

Anyway, Panmure on iomart was requested so here it is.

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

While iomart’s share price is roughly where it was in 2013, it has since then
doubled revenue and profits through a combination of organic growth and bolt-on
acquisitions. Including potential future acquisitions (not in forecasts), we think it
should maintain mid-teens growth in revenue and EBITDA consistent with the past
few years making the shares attractively priced at 9.4x FY’18 EBITDA. This
compares to other UK Technology midcaps at 16.0x on the same expectation of 15%
EBITDA growth p.a. We initiate with a buy rating and price target of 430p.
 Competitive threats overblown: Our checks in the industry confirm that iomart has
an established role to play in the cloud computing market segment, which has
recently been dominated by hyperscale public cloud vendors Amazon (AWS), Microsoft
(Azure) and Google (GCP). This is echoed by public cloud provider’s offerings in the
marketplace which are more tailored to larger companies.
 Share price roughly the same despite the company doubling in size: Despite the
share price being only slightly higher than it was four years ago, iomart has doubled
revenue and profits (both pre-and-post tax) and seems to have settled into a
consistent level of high single digit organic growth, complemented by acquisitions.

BE12:08pm

 High quality revenue and a potential acquisition target: While we think iomart could
grow faster if it wanted to, it only takes business where it can add the most value
which thereby keeps its margins high. Now that the company is tipping the £100m
mark in revenue, we think it could become more attractive to a private equity buyer.
 Increasing asset efficiency and cash generation: Since FY’14A, the amount of capex it
spends has been decreasing as a portion of revenue as it gets more out of its datacentre
assets with a focus on higher quality revenue and has also produced increases in free
cash flow.
 Compelling valuation: With 90%+ recurring revenue, c40% EBITDA margins, expected
growth in the mid-teens, a 7.5% maintenance FCF yield and a 2.0% dividend yield we
think iomart's shares are attractively valued at 9.4x EBITDA. Our initial price target of
430p equates to 12x FY’18 EV/EBITDA and is supported by discounted cash flow
analysis and a comparable company analysis. Our valuation does not include the
value of potential future acquisitions and we therefore feel it is conservative.

BE12:09pm

Peter McNally and Sanjay Jha are the analysts.

12:09 pm
undefined
BE12:10pm

Okay, I think we're done. Apologies that we weren't too slick this morning. Various forces were against us.

BE12:11pm

No matter. Back tomorrow, to fail better.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:37am

Meanwhile, the ever-interesting Sandy Morris of Jefferies has a rather more considered view.
